Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Lesser Occipital and Greater Auricular Nerve Block for Analgesia in Vestibular Schwannoma Craniotomy

Background: This study aimed to assess the analgesic efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided lesser occipital nerve block combined with greater auricular nerve block (LOGAB) in patients undergoing vestibular schwannoma resection via a suboccipital retrosigmoid approach.

Methods: Conducted as a prospective, double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 62 patients aged 18-64 years were recruited at Tongji Hospital, China. Eligible participants were randomly assigned to receive either LOGAB with 5 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine (n=31) or normal saline (n=31). The primary outcome was the numeric rating scale (NRS) scores at rest and motion within 48 hours post-surgery. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed in sealed envelopes. Blinding included patients, outcome assessors, and clinicians.

Results: A total of 59 patients were analysed (30 in LOGAB group, 29 in control group) using an intention-to-treat approach. NRS scores at rest were significantly lower in the LOGAB group compared to control (mean difference = 1.4, 95% CI 0.9 to 1.9; p=0.002). NRS scores at motion were significantly lower at 6 and 12 hours post-surgery in the LOGAB group (p<0.05). Intraoperative opioid consumption was reduced in the LOGAB group (p<0.01). Postoperative remedial analgesia was required earlier in the control group (p<0.001). No adverse events were reported in either group.

Interpretation: LOGAB is a promising analgesic strategy for vestibular schwannoma craniotomy, effectively reducing pain and opioid use without adverse events. It also maintains intraoperative hemodynamic stability.

Trial registration: ChiCTR2000038798.

Funding: Not specified.
